010package imagingbook.common.noise.hashing;
011
012/**
013 * <p>
014 * Permutation-based hash function, similar to the one proposed in [1]. See [2]
015 * for details.
016 * </p>
017 * <p>
018 * [1] K. Perlin. An image synthesizer. SIGGRAPH Computer Graphics 19(3),
019 * 287â€“296 (1985). <br>
020 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Principles of Digital Image Processing &ndash;
021 * Advanced Methods</em> (Vol. 3), Supplementary Chapter 8: "Synthetic Gradient
022 * Noise", Springer (2013). <a href=
023 * "https://dx.doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.1.3427.7284">https://dx.doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.1.3427.7284</a>
024 * </p>
025 * 
026 * @author WB
027 * @version 2022/11/24
028 */
029public class HashPermute implements HashFunction {
030        
031        private final int seed;
032        
033        /**
034         * Constructor, creates a hash function with a random seed value.
035         */
036        HashPermute() {
037                this(0);
038        }
039        
040        /**
041         * Constructor creating a hash function with the specified seed value.
042         * @param seed the random seed value (set to 0 use a random seed value).
043         */
044        public HashPermute(int seed) {
045                this.seed = HashFunction.getRandomSeed(seed);
046        }
047        
048        @Override
049        public double hash(int u) {
050                int h = h8(u);
051                return (double) (h & 0xFF) / 0xFF; // use bits 0..7 for d
052        }
053        
054        // 6 bits per channel (overlapping blocks)
055        @Override
056        public double[] hash(int u, int v) {
057                final int M = 0x3F; // 63;
058                int h = h8(u, v);
059                double hx = h & M;                      // use bits 0..5 for dx
060                double hy = (h >> 2) & M;       // use bits 2..7 for dy
061                return new double[] {hx/M, hy/M};
062        }
063        
064        @Override
065        public double[] hash(int u, int v, int w) {
066                final int M = 0x0F;
067                int h = h8(u, v, w);
068                double hx =  h & M;                     // use bits 0..3 for x
069                double hy = ((h >> 2) & M);     // use bits 2..5 for y
070                double hz = ((h >> 4) & M);     // use bits 4..7 for z
071                return new double[] {hx/M, hy/M, hz/M};
072        }
073
074        // 2 dimensions
075        private int h8 (int u) {
076                u = (u + seed) & 0xFF;
077                return P[u];
078        }
079        
080        // 2 dimensions
081        private int h8 (int u, int v) {
082                u = (u + seed) & 0xFF;
083                v = v & 0xFF;
084                return P[P[v] + u];
085        }
086        
087        // 3 dimensions
088        private int h8 (int u, int v, int w) {
089                u = (u + seed) & 0xFF;
090                v = v & 0xFF;
091                w = w & 0xFF;
092                return P[P[P[w] + v] + u];
093        }
094        
095        @Override
096        /*
097         * N-dimensional permutation hash; this version does not use
098         * any bit splitting. Instead, the hash8() function is
099         * applied repeatedly for every gradient dimension by 
100         * using the dimension number (k) as a local seed (sd) - 
101         * in addition to the global seed (seed).
102         */
103        public double[] hash(int[] p) {
104                int N = p.length;
105                double[] g = new double[N];
106                for (int k = 0; k < N; k++) {           // dimension k
107                        int h = h8(p, k + seed);
108                        g[k] = (double) (h & 0xFF) / 0xFF;
109                }
110                return g;
111        }
112        
113        /*
114         * N-dimensional permutation hash function
115         */
116        private int h8 (int[] p, int sd) {
117                int h = sd & 0xFF;
118                for (int k = 0; k < p.length; k++) {
119                        h = P[h + p[k] & 0xFF];
120                }
121                return h;
122        }
123
124        /*
125         * Permutation table P[i], for i = 0..255. To avoid index wrapping, 
126         * table's length is doubled to 512.
127         */
128        static final int P[] = new int[512];
129        static {
130                int[] perm = {
131                                151, 160, 137, 91, 90, 15, 131, 13, 
132                                201, 95, 96, 53, 194, 233, 7, 225, 
133                                140, 36, 103, 30, 69, 142, 8, 99, 
134                                37, 240, 21, 10, 23, 190, 6, 148, 
135                                247, 120, 234, 75, 0, 26, 197, 62,
136                                94,     252, 219, 203, 117, 35, 11, 32, 
137                                57, 177, 33, 88, 237, 149, 56, 87, 
138                                174, 20, 125, 136, 171, 168, 68, 175, 
139                                74, 165, 71, 134, 139, 48, 27, 166, 
140                                77, 146, 158, 231, 83, 111, 229, 122, 
141                                60, 211, 133, 230, 220, 105, 92, 41, 
142                                55, 46, 245, 40, 244, 102, 143, 54, 
143                                65, 25, 63, 161, 1, 216, 80, 73, 
144                                209, 76, 132, 187, 208, 89, 18, 169, 
145                                200, 196, 135, 130, 116, 188, 159, 86, 
146                                164, 100, 109, 198, 173, 186, 3, 64,
147                                52, 217, 226, 250, 124, 123, 5, 202, 
148                                38, 147, 118, 126, 255, 82, 85, 212, 
149                                207, 206, 59, 227, 47, 16, 58, 17, 
150                                182, 189, 28, 42, 223, 183, 170, 213, 
151                                119, 248, 152, 2, 44, 154, 163, 70, 
152                                221, 153, 101, 155, 167, 43, 172, 9,
153                                129, 22, 39, 253, 19, 98, 108, 110, 
154                                79, 113, 224, 232, 178, 185, 112, 104,
155                                218, 246, 97, 228, 251, 34, 242, 193, 
156                                238, 210, 144, 12, 191, 179, 162, 241, 
157                                81, 51, 145, 235, 249, 14, 239, 107, 
158                                49, 192, 214, 31, 181, 199, 106, 157, 
159                                184, 84, 204, 176, 115, 121, 50, 45, 
160                                127, 4, 150, 254, 138, 236, 205, 93, 
161                                222, 114, 67, 29, 24, 72, 243, 141, 
162                                128, 195, 78, 66, 215, 61, 156, 180 };
163                for (int i = 0; i < 256; i++)
164                        P[256 + i] = P[i] = perm[i];
165        }
166        
167//      public static void main(String[] args) {
168//              HashPermute hf = new HashPermute();
169//              for (int k = 0; k < 256; k++) {
170//                      System.out.format("%d : %10f\n", k, hf.hash(k));
171//                      
172//              }
173//      }
174}
